page.title: 09FARMING
page.content: The surrounding landscape is an hist- orical document. Farming has its roots in the Anglo-Saxon settlements and the Normans established the concept of large rural estates, tenancy farming and the rural village society. The socio-economic structure of this area was built on farming and today it is still the principle industry. It is now highly mechanised and the need for increased efficiency and profitability has greatly reduced the demand for labour. Many small holdings have been incorporated into larger units and, except for Langham Park Farm, the farms on the Bourne Estate are farmed as one. A few small farms remain, some owned, some rented, but all less than 200 acres. Management of trees has improved and a replanting scheme begun in the 1950s continues, mainly hard- wood, conifer and chestnut coppice.
